nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change are severely underestimated and models calibrated to them (notably DICE) are unsuitable for assessing climate risk or informing policy
Many economic damage assessments assume climatic tipping points will not be triggered this century or assign them negligible probability
A common methodological error is equating weather-exposed activities with all climate vulnerability and excluding indoor/controlled sectors from damages

Using current spatial correlations between temperature and regional income as a proxy to predict future global climate impacts is invalid because regional equilibria, trade, and different physical mechanisms over time differ from spatial variation

Integrated Assessment Models and studies feeding IAMs share data and methodological dependencies so flawed empirical estimates propagate across models and policy metrics like the Social Cost of Carbon

The DICE model structure and its economic assumptions (representative agent Ramsey growth, Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous TFP and full employment, saddle-path stability) mathematically prevent endogenous economic collapse even under extreme damage specifications
Scientific literature (Lenton et al. and follow-ups) identifies multiple climate tipping elements that could be triggered within this century and possible tipping cascades amplifying global change
IPCC and cited empirical studies show very modest central damage estimates (e.g. ~2.1% at 3C in Nordhaus, scatter of small impacts in IPCC Fig 10.1) that treat damages as small relative to growth

Numerical sensitivity analysis of DICE shows that even when damage coefficient is increased to produce damages near 90% of GDP the model either yields corner-case full mitigation solutions and eventual recovery or becomes infeasible, but does not produce endogenous economic collapse
Including scientifically elicited tipping point likelihoods in DICE-like models substantially increases estimated damages and the Social Cost of Carbon (examples report >8-fold increase)

The principal empirical methods used by economists to estimate damages are flawed: enumeration that omits broad sectors, statistical cross-sectional spatial proxies, CGE models assuming equilibrium adaptation, and small expert elicitation samples with divergent views

Given the conceptual, methodological, data and structural modelling flaws, economists' empirical damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them should be rejected for evaluating economic risks of climate change and for policy formation
Critiques within economics have focused on discounting, uncertainty and equilibrium suitability but have not adequately challenged the veracity of the low numerical damage estimates themselves
